Description: Pottery mould-made round oil-lamp with protruding nozzle of red fabric; the shoulder has decoration of dots and semi-circles in low relief; the base has raised ring; no handle. Traces of burning at nozzle. Clay brown, micaceous, with lime inclusions, Nile silt (though perhaps not from Naukratis itself?).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Early Roman parallels in the British Museum (Bailey 1975, Q565-70). Late 2nd century BC (or later) parallel from Alexandria (Mlynarczyk 1998, 338, Fig. 9, see n. 29). End of the 2nd century BC to early 1st century AD parallels from Tell Atrib (Młynarczyk 2012, type TA 11.6). Mlynarczyk, J. 1998. Terracotta mould-made lamps in Alexandria (Hellenistic to Late Roman period), in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 327-52. Młynarczyk, J. 2012. Tell Atrib 1985-1995. Vol. 3: Terracotta oil lamps. Varsovie : Éditions Neriton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.058) (Phase 3)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4854 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
